presentation.title: Git - Source code control for humans
presentation.author: Andrew Ruthven / Evan Giles

slide.title: Overview
slide.bullet: Why use revision control?
Why use git?
Create a new repository
Managing files
Change logs
Branching
Merging
Remote repositories

slide.title: Why use revision control?
slide.bullet: Track software
View history
Look back to find when bugs where created
Reasoning behind why something is how it is
Roll back changes
Apply kudos for effort
Backups of your important stuff
slide.notes: Without revision control you end up with countless copies of files with no idea what is what. Anecdote - files called readme.tt, readme.ttt, readme.tttt

slide.title: What options are there?
slide.bullet: Lots of options...
RCS
CVS
Subversion
Darcs
Perforce
Bzr

slide.title: Why not use git?
slide.bullet: There are some new concepts
There are sooo many commands!
You can safely ignore most of those commands.
When you do want to send patches as emails, the command is there.
When you want to import patches from a mailbox, the command is there.
You get the idea.

slide.title: Why should you use git?
slide.bullet: The cool kids use it (including the Koha devs)
It is fast
As light weight as RCS, but much better!
Branching is trivial
Merging of branches actually makes sense
You can be disconnected from the network, yet still continue working
Once you master the concepts, you can do some really creative (and useful!) stuff

slide.title: Installing
slide.code: # Required sudo aptitude install git-core
# Almost required :) sudo aptitude install gitk
# See also... sudo aptitude search git

slide.title: Configuring
slide.bullet: Global data is stoed in $HOME/.git/config
Project data is stoed in $PROJECT/.git/config
use git config to see and modify it
..or vim
Not actually required

slide.title: Some concepts to begin with
slide.bullet: git is just a bit different
You get a checkout - so you can work with your project
You get an index, which can be used to prepare commits
You get a local repository, which will hold all your commits
The local repository can be aware of multiple branches
Some branches are remote

slide.title: Create a new repository
slide.bullet: Use git init
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git init Initialized empty Git repository in .git/ puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: Check the status with git status
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git status # On branch master # # Initial commit # nothing to commit (create/copy files and use "git add" to track) puck@dirk:/tmp/test$

slide.title: Managing Files - Add
slide.bullet: Make some changes...
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ touch super-script.pl

puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git status # On branch master # # Initial commit # # Untracked files: # (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed) # # super-script.pl nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
slide.bullet: Tell git about files with git add <files>
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git add super-script.pl
puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git status # On branch master # # Initial commit # # Changes to be committed: # (use "git rm --cached <file>..." to unstage) # # new file: super-script.pl # puck@dirk:/tmp/test$

slide.title: Managing Files - Change an existing file
slide.bullet: Make some changes...
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ echo DATA > super-script.pl

puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git status # On branch master # # Initial commit # # Changes to be committed: # (use "git rm --cached <file>..." to unstage) # # new file: super-script.pl # # Changed but not updated: # (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed) # (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory) # # modified: super-script.pl #
slide.bullet: ...so, git is saying that it knows you have changed the file since you added it
Ie. The version in the checkout is different to the version in the index
We need to tell git that you intend to commit the checked out version, with git add <files>
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git add super-script.pl
puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git status # On branch master # # Initial commit # # Changes to be committed: # (use "git rm --cached <file>..." to unstage) # # new file: super-script.pl #

slide.title: Commiting changes
slide.bullet: We have told git about our changes
We haven't actually committed anything yet
This is deliberate - so you can build up more complex commits
Every change needs to be committed
Commit with git commit <files>
You will be asked for a commit message (please include the WR number)
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git commit super-script.pl Created commit ae54011: Add a message. 1 files changed, 3 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-) create mode 100644 super-script.pl puck@dirk:/tmp/test$

slide.title: Commiting changes - some useful options
slide.bullet: You don't have to add all your changes manually
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git commit <file>
puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git commit -a
slide.bullet: You don't have to use an editor...
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git commit -m 'commit message goes here'

slide.title: Managing Files - Permissions
slide.bullet: Oops, that file isn't executable
Unlike some revision control systems, git is aware of file permissions
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ chmod 755 super-script.pl puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git commit super-script.pl Created commit 378af93: Make it executable. 0 files changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-) mode change 100644 => 100755 super-script.pl puck@dirk:/tmp/test$

slide.title: Managing Files - Move
slide.bullet: To rename a file use git mv <source> <dest>
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git mv super-script.pl silly-script.pl
puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git status # On branch master # Changes to be committed: # (use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage) # # renamed: super-script.pl -> silly-script.pl # puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: This has changed our checkout, and the index, so we are ready to commit the change
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git commit Created commit fabd446: Rename the file. 1 files changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-) rename super-script.pl => silly-script.pl (100%) puck@dirk:/tmp/test$

slide.title: Managing Files - Delete
slide.bullet: To delete a file use git rm <files>
slide.code: # This won't actually work, because we haven't created "another-script.pl" # ... but you can try it, if you like....
puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git rm another-script.pl
puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git status # On branch master # Changes to be committed: # (use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage) # # deleted: another-script.pl # puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: And commit the change
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git commit Created commit bd10c5f: Remove another-script.pl 0 files changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-) delete mode 100644 another-script.pl puck@dirk:/tmp/test$

slide.title: Change Logs
slide.bullet: See what is going on
Use git log
By default the output is piped into $PAGER
slide.code:
puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git log commit bd10c5f5179b4c6b52d586cc5355e3018b3c8c37 Author: Andrew Ruthven <puck@catalyst.net.nz> Date: Fri May 9 17:08:02 2008 +1200
Remove another-script.pl
commit cc260920d4b1aa87e000d2a52643b22b725d4922 Author: Andrew Ruthven <puck@catalyst.net.nz> Date: Fri May 9 17:07:35 2008 +1200
Add a test script.
commit fabd44619bd37f47b9e1e193ee4ded97e64f8f4a Author: Andrew Ruthven <puck@catalyst.net.nz> Date: Fri May 9 17:03:04 2008 +1200
Rename the file.
commit 378af932284a01c8cb6c3de202182ecac0fa7969 Author: Andrew Ruthven <puck@catalyst.net.nz> Date: Fri May 9 17:02:24 2008 +1200
Make it executable.
commit ae540117822f58ca7974c69fe13270959cc04f34 Author: Andrew Ruthven <puck@catalyst.net.nz> Date: Fri May 9 17:01:41 2008 +1200
Add a message. puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git log | cat commit bd10c5f5179b4c6b52d586cc5355e3018b3c8c37 Author: Andrew Ruthven <puck@catalyst.net.nz> Date: Fri May 9 17:08:02 2008 +1200
Remove another-script.pl
commit cc260920d4b1aa87e000d2a52643b22b725d4922 Author: Andrew Ruthven <puck@catalyst.net.nz> Date: Fri May 9 17:07:35 2008 +1200
Add a test script.
commit fabd44619bd37f47b9e1e193ee4ded97e64f8f4a Author: Andrew Ruthven <puck@catalyst.net.nz> Date: Fri May 9 17:03:04 2008 +1200
Rename the file.
commit 378af932284a01c8cb6c3de202182ecac0fa7969 Author: Andrew Ruthven <puck@catalyst.net.nz> Date: Fri May 9 17:02:24 2008 +1200
Make it executable.
commit ae540117822f58ca7974c69fe13270959cc04f34 Author: Andrew Ruthven <puck@catalyst.net.nz> Date: Fri May 9 17:01:41 2008 +1200
Add a message. puck@dirk:/tmp/test$

slide.title: Change Logs
slide.bullet: Can specify a file or directory
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git log silly-script.pl

slide.title: Change Logs - Annotate
slide.bullet: Show who made changes to what line
Also known as the blame log
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git blame silly-script.pl puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git blame silly-script.pl | cat ^ae54011 super-script.pl (Andrew Ruthven 2008-05-09 17:01:41 +1200 1) #!/usr/bin/perl -w ^ae54011 super-script.pl (Andrew Ruthven 2008-05-09 17:01:41 +1200 2) ^ae54011 super-script.pl (Andrew Ruthven 2008-05-09 17:01:41 +1200 3) print "silly script\n"; 2c08faf4 silly-script.pl (Bad Coder 2008-05-09 17:18:18 +1200 4) I'm in ur code, breaking ur stuff. puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: Who is this Bad Coder fella?

slide.title: Change Logs - GUI
slide.bullet: Not strictly change logs, but...
gitk
git gui
Many more
( Demo )

slide.title: Some more concepts - commits
slide.bullet: It is important to understand that git thinks in commits
Each commit builds upon a previous commit
Each commit refers to a previous commit (it's parent)
...and a series of commits provide a complete history of the project
gitk lets you visualise the commit history, which helps a lot
Commits can be referenced by their SHA1 checksum
- or an abbreviation of it
- or by a number of things that might refer to them

slide.title: Branching - List
slide.bullet: To show branches use git branch
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git branch * master puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: Only one branch called master
The '*' indicates that it is your current branch

slide.title: Branching - Create
slide.bullet: Use git checkout -b <new-name>
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git checkout -b new-branch Switched to a new branch "new-branch" puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git branch master * new-branch puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: Will create "new-branch", and check it out for you
new-branch will be created at the commit your previously had checked out
Can also create a new branch at another location
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git checkout -b another-branch master Switched to a new branch "another-branch" puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git branch * another-branch master new-branch puck@dirk:/tmp/test$

slide.title: Branching - Change Branch
slide.bullet: Just use git checkout without the -b
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git checkout new-branch Switched to branch "new-branch" puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git branch another-branch master * new-branch puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: Don't forget to see how this is shown in gitk

slide.title: Branching - What's the deal?
slide.bullet: You can make commits on a branch without polluting other branches
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ echo "# From new-branch" >> silly-script.pl puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git commit silly-script.pl Created commit a6ed2cf: From new-branch 1 files changed, 1 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-) puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: Check the file, then jump to another branch, it ain't there

slide.title: Branching - Why?
slide.bullet: Many (most) projects have a branch for each release
Branches are useful for experimntal features / refactoring
Branches happen (without even trying) when several people try to work on the same project - but I'll explain that soon ;)

slide.title: Merging - Simple Case
slide.bullet: You should now be on the master branch
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git status # On branch master nothing to commit (working directory clean) puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: Just say git merge <other branch>
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git merge new-branch Updating e766bfb..a6ed2cf Fast forward silly-script.pl | 1 + 1 files changed, 1 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-) puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: If there are no conflicts, this will make a new commit object
In this case the commit message is automatically created
slide.code:
Merge branch 'new-branch'
Conflicts:
silly-script.pl

slide.title: Merging - How does it look?
slide.bullet: Looking at the trees in gitk is cool.

slide.title: Merging - With conflicts
slide.bullet: Conflicts are more difficult
If there are conflicts then git will stop and let you fix it.
Lots of tools to help fix things up. Hand edit, xxdiff, smartmerge, etc
slide.code:
puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git merge new-branch Auto-merged silly-script.pl CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in silly-script.pl Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result. puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ cat silly-script.pl #!/usr/bin/perl -w
<<<<<<< HEAD:silly-script.pl print "silly script - change on master\n"; ======= print "change on new-branch - silly script\n"; >>>>>>> new-branch:silly-script.pl # From new-branch puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: Fix it, in this case use vi
Now that we've fixed the code, tell git that it has been fixed and commit it
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git add silly-script.pl puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git commit Created commit a411f2a: Merge branch 'new-branch' puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: In this case the commit message is automatically created
slide.code:
Merge branch 'new-branch'
Conflicts:
silly-script.pl

slide.title: Creating Repositories - Revisted
slide.bullet: There are many different ways to get remote repositories, some are:
Create a new one (we've already covered this)
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git init Initialized empty Git repository in .git/ puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: In practise, you're more likely to use git clone <URL> <local dir>
<local dir> is optional
To check out the source code for this course
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp$ git clone git+ssh://gitprivate.catalyst.net.nz/git/private/git-training.git Cloning into git-training... remote: Counting objects: 90, done. remote: Compressing objects: 100% (43/43), done. remote: Total 90 (delta 44), reused 90 (delta 44) Receiving objects: 100% (90/90), 31.62 KiB, done. Resolving deltas: 100% (44/44), done. puck@dirk:/tmp$
puck@dirk:/tmp$ cd git-training puck@dirk:/tmp/git-training$ ls talk.xml talk.xml

slide.title: Remote repositories - URLs
slide.bullet: Clone an existing repository via HTTP
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp$ git clone http://gitprivate.catalyst.net.nz/git-training-example.git
slide.bullet: Clone an existing repository via SSH
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp$ git clone git+ssh://git.catalyst.net.nz/git/private/git-training-example.git
slide.bullet: Clone an existing repository Local repository (this is just a bit mad)
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp$ git clone test test2

slide.title: Sharing your changes with others
slide.bullet: git fetch
git merge
git rebase
git push
git pull
Discuss....

slide.title: Abort a change (early)
slide.bullet: What if you screw things up?
If the error is just in you checkout, you can run git reset --hard
This throws away all local changes, except unknown files
You could also use gitk

slide.title: Abort a change.. (not that early)
slide.bullet: What if you screw things up?
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ echo "I am sooo drunk!" > silly-script.pl
slide.bullet: ... and tell git we are going to commit something
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git add silly-script.pl puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git status # On branch master # Changes to be committed: # (use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage) # # modified: silly-script.pl #
slide.bullet: ... and then decide that it was all a mistake
Use git reset to undo the git add
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git reset HEAD silly-script.pl silly-script.pl: needs update
slide.bullet: And git checkout to undo the edit
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git checkout silly-script.pl puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git status # On branch master nothing to commit (working directory clean) puck@dirk:/tmp/test$
slide.bullet: You could also use gitk

slide.title: Abort a change (late)
slide.bullet: Sometimes we want to undo a commit
Many different ways, one way to leave an audit trail:
slide.code: puck@dirk:/tmp/test$ git revert 2c08faf4 Finished one revert. Created commit e766bfb: Revert "Break the code!" 1 files changed, 0 insertions(+), 1 deletions(-) puck@dirk:/tmp/test$

slide.title: The End
slide.bullet: Questions?
http://www.eecs.harvard.edu/~cduan/technical/git/
http://www.alistapart.com/articles/get-started-with-git/
